description: A popular and capable suppressor, <suppressor_loudness>.  <suppressor_rating_556>  <suppressor_too_short>  <suppressor_no_direct_thread>  Instead, it mounts onto a SOCOM muzzle brake, also from SureFire.  <suppressor_descriptor>

notes: the higher-diameter collar is reflected in the negative trim value

//integral_longest_side: absorbs the length of the SureFire SOCOM muzzle brake it mounts onto (66 mm)

description: A large, potent suppressor, <suppressor_loudness>.  <suppressor_rating_rifle_wide>  <suppressor_no_direct_thread>  Instead, it mounts onto the SR muzzle brake, also from Thunder Beast Arms.  <suppressor_descriptor>

notes: the higher-diameter collar is reflected in the negative trim value

//integral_longest_side: Dominus-SR covers the muzzle brake it mounts on completely, absorbing its length (57 mm)

//notes: for now, we assume this to be a direct-thread model of Ultra 9 Gen 2
if the HUB interface expansion kicks off in Loadout or Gunsmith, we'll move it to HUB

name.str: Thunder Beast Arms Ultra 9 Gen 2 suppressor

notes: the lower-diameter collar is reflected in the trim value

//integral_longest_side: being direct-thread-mounted, absorbs the regular 16 mm of threading on a 1/2 in. × 28-threaded barrel
//acceptable_ammo: due to a wide range of calibers, we simply leave this able to be installed on any caliber for the time being

description: An unassuming model of a suppressor, <suppressor_loudness>.  <suppressor_rating_556_300blk>  <suppressor_no_direct_thread>  Instead, it mounts onto the QD-7 flash hider, also from Silent Legion.  <suppressor_descriptor>
//integral_longest_side: absorbs the length of the Silent Legion QD-7 flash hider (35 mm)

//notes: short 7 in. version without tube extension
description: A slim and potent suppressor, <suppressor_loudness>.  This model is primarily rated for .308 cal., but it can handle anything between .17 cal. and .300 Weatherby.  <suppressor_direct_thread>  <suppressor_descriptor>

notes: the lower-diameter collar is reflected in the trim value

//integral_longest_side: being direct-thread-mounted, absorbs the regular 16 mm of threading on a 1/2 in. × 28-threaded barrel
//acceptable_ammo: due to a wide range of calibers, we simply leave this able to be installed on any caliber for the time being

//notes: comes with and mounts onto Elite Iron Bravo 1 muzzle brake
given that there's very little information about the brake, and since the suppressor comes with the brake, we pretend it's a direct-thread mount
for future reference: the muzzle brake's length (from visual reference) is 2.55 in.
description: An unassuming suppressor made of titanium, <suppressor_loudnes>>.  <suppressor_rating_rifle_wide>  <suppressor_direct_thread_via_brake>  <suppressor_descriptor>
//integral_longest_side: being direct-thread-mounted, absorbs the regular 16 mm of threading on a 1/2 in. × 28-threaded barrel

//notes: this one assumes maximum-length configuration of 4.6 in., though the suppressor is configurable all the way down to 1.9 in.
description: A uniquely-designed suppressor, <suppressor_loudness>.  This model is rated primarily for pistol calibers, such as 9×19mm Parabellum, .30 Super Carry, and .357 Magnum.  <suppressor_direct_thread>  <suppressor_descriptor>
//weight: 2.5 oz ≈ 71 g in the 4.6 in. configuration
//integral_longest_side: comes with an optional adapter for the M13.5×1LH thread, where thread length is between 0.400 and 0.438 in. ≈ 10 mm and 11 mm
defaults to a 1/2 in. × 28 mount, making thread length 16 mm
//acceptable_ammo: source requires .357 Magnum to have a 16-in. minimum barrel length
//loudness_modifier: -32 should be effective for 9mm, given that (as of 2023-08-08) 9mm JHP's computed loudness is 80
anecdotal evidence suggests that this suppressor is not that effective, though video tests show quite the opposite

description: A dated-yet-capable suppressor from Knights Armament Co., <suppressor_loudness>.  It's primarily known for being used on U.S. military rifles for more than two decades.  <suppressor_rating_556>  <suppressor_too_short>  <suppressor_no_direct_thread>  Instead, it mounts onto an M4QD muzzle brake, also from KAC.  <suppressor_descriptor>

variants.description: A dated-yet-capable suppressor from Knights Armament Co., colored black, <suppressor_loudness>.  It's primarily known for being used on U.S. military rifles for more than two decades.  <suppressor_rating_556>  <suppressor_too_short>  <suppressor_no_direct_thread>  Instead, it mounts onto an M4QD muzzle brake, also from KAC.  <suppressor_descriptor>

A dated-yet-capable suppressor from Knights Armament Co., colored tan, <suppressor_loudness>.  It's primarily known for being used on U.S. military rifles for more than two decades.  <suppressor_rating_556>  <suppressor_too_short>  <suppressor_no_direct_thread>  Instead, it mounts onto an M4QD muzzle brake, also from KAC.  <suppressor_descriptor>

notes: the higher-diameter collar is reflected in the negative trim value

//integral_longest_side: absorbs the length of the KAC M4QD muzzle brake it mounts onto (48 mm)
//loudness_modifier: the review puts this suppressor's performance slightly below SOCOM556-RC2 (at least with muzzle score)
SOCOM556-RC2's own score in this mod is -45
the overall sentiment for QDSS' performance is that despite its faulty design, it performs equal to or even better than some current market options
